bibl.title: Capital in the Sixth Century: The Dynamics of Tax and Estate in Roman Egypt
bibl.seg: Gilles Bransbourg, Capital in the Sixth Century: The Dynamics of Tax and Estate in Roman Egypt.
Journal of Late Antiquity 9 (2016) pp. 305-414, figg.

Introduction. - Part 1. The sources: The documentary corpus and the issues at stake; - The main sources. - Part 2. Sixth-century taxation in the Antaeopolite - and possibly elsewhere in Egypt: The structure of sixth-century taxation; - Tax rates; - Further issues; - Tax rates fluctuation in the sixth century. - Part 3. The dynamics of a large estate in the sixth century - the Apiones dossier: The Apiones and the Cynopolite nome; - Embolē rates and transportation fees; - The Apiones' gardens; - The villages whose tax payments were managed by the Apiones; - The area administered by the Apiones for tax purposes; - The Apiones: a house of privilege?; - Adaeration and the Apiones; - Adaeratio and the Apiones "unwanted" grain surplus; - The Apiones' profit equation; - The size of the Apiones estate between the 540s and the 580s; - Agricultural surplus, rent, and tax on the Apiones estates; - The Apiones as (non)entrepreneurs; - Did the end of Justinian's reign witness a "Laffer curve" situation?; - The disposition of agricultural rent; - Maintaining the flow of gold from Egypt in a context of lower taxation; - The uneven rise and fall of the Apiones; - How about the plague? - Conclusion.
